content:
In what follows all my categories, functors, equivalence etc. will be Ab-enriched.

Usually you can't recover a ring from its category of modules. Indeed, we say two rings are Morita equivalent if their categories of module are equivalent, and any ring RRR is Morita equivalent to the ring of n×nn \times nn×n matrices with entries in RRR.
However, it should be possible to recover a commutative ring from its category of modules.

My evidence for this is Prop. 21.10 in Anderson and Fuller's Rings and Categories of Modules.

(I've owned this book for decades but only recently am I exploring the relevant sections. Now it strikes me how much work they do to show things work the same way in equivalent categories - things that seem obvious. Maybe that means this book is good for people who don't yet "get" category theory.)
This proposition says that if two rings are Morita equivalent, their centers are isomorphic.
But I'd much rather hear a theorem that says how to read off the center of a ring from its category of modules!

And staring at the proof, I think we might be able to do it this way. Suppose MMM is any projective generator of the category Mod(R)\mathsf{Mod}(R)Mod(R). Here MMM is a generator if for every object XXX there's an epimorphism from some (possibly infinite) sum of copies of MMM to XXX.
Then I believe the center of the ring of endomorphisms of MMM (that is, RRR-module endomorphisms) is isomorphic to the center of RRR!

If this is true then we're done, since for every ring RRR, the category Mod(R)\mathsf{Mod}(R)Mod(R) has a projective generator: for example RRR itself. So we just take any one, and take center of its ring of endomorphisms, and that's the center of RRR.
And the important part is that we don't need to know RRR ahead of time to tell what objects in Mod(R)\mathsf{Mod}(R)Mod(R) are projective generators.
However, I'm not completely sure of the logic of Anderson and Fuller's proof (it uses a bunch of facts proved elsewhere, and at least one of the references back to those facts seems wrong).

In particular I'm not really sure of this:

  • if MMM is a projective generator in Mod(R)\mathsf{Mod}(R)Mod(R), the center of the endomorphism ring of MMM is the center of RRR.
I'm afraid this may be true only for finitely generated projective generators, and unfortunately it seems we do need to know RRR ahead of time to tell what objects in RRR are finitely generated.
We'll see who among you knows a bunch about rings and modules! It's funny how this sort of math doesn't show up much in programming or "applied" category theory.

Hmm, maybe there's a better way to recover a commutative ring RRR from the Ab-enriched category Mod(R)\mathsf{Mod}(R)Mod(R). Here's another attempt. Since RRR is commutative, every element r∈Rr \in Rr∈R acts as an endomorphism of each RRR-module MMM, namely multiplication by rrr.

If I'm not getting myself confused, these fit together to give a natural transformation from 1:Mod(R)→Mod(R)1: \mathsf{Mod}(R)\to \mathsf{Mod}(R)1:Mod(R)→Mod(R) to itself.
It seems that natural transformations from 111 to itself form a ring under composition and addition, say End(1Mod(R))\mathrm{End}(1_{\mathsf{Mod}(R)})End(1Mod(R)​).

So it seems we have a ring homomorphism

m:R→End(1Mod(R))m : \mathrm{R} \to \mathrm{End}(1_{\mathsf{Mod}(R)})m:R→End(1Mod(R)​)
And this is injective, since distinct elements of RRR act differently on the left RRR-module that's RRR itself.

So if it were surjective too, then we'd get

R≅End(1Mod(R)) R \cong \mathrm{End}(1_{\mathsf{Mod}(R)})R≅End(1Mod(R)​)

(in the commutative case).
Sounds like the [[center of an additive category]].

Yes, thanks.

So now I either need to plow through some French and hope Gabriel proved what I want, or figure it out myself. :upside_down:

I'm thinking I can show

R≅End(1Mod(R)) R \cong \mathrm{End}(1_{\mathsf{Mod}(R)})R≅End(1Mod(R)​)

is surjective roughly as follows. Suppose m:1Mod(R))⇒1Mod(R))m: 1_{\mathsf{Mod}(R)}) \Rightarrow 1_{\mathsf{Mod}(R)})m:1Mod(R)​)⇒1Mod(R)​) is a natural transformation. Then on the object R∈Mod(R)R \in \mathsf{Mod}(R)R∈Mod(R), mR:R→Rm_R: R \to RmR​:R→R is just multiplication by some r∈Rr \in Rr∈R. By naturality this is also how it must work on every free module (that is, any sum of copies of RRR). Then... here's the part where I should slow down and think a bit more... since every module is the quotient of a free module, on every module our natural transformation must be just multiplication by this r∈Rr \in Rr∈R.

I think that's right: I take any module MMM, write it as a quotient of a free module

∑αR→M→0 \sum_{\alpha} R \to M \to 0∑α​R→M→0

and use naturality to draw a little commutative diagram where on the left side going down you have multiplication by rrr on each summand.
I was just about to answer that's its surjective
Okay, great!

My proof is that you want to show that any natural transformation α:1MOD(R)⇒1MOD(R)\alpha: 1_{MOD(R)} \Rightarrow 1_{MOD(R)}α:1MOD(R)​⇒1MOD(R)​ is a of the form αM(m)=r⋅m\alpha_M(m) = r \cdot mαM​(m)=r⋅m for some r∈Rr \in Rr∈R for all RRR-modules MMM

Now consider the case M=RM=RM=R, we get an RRR-linear map αR:R→R\alpha_R: R \to RαR​:R→R. But RRR-linear maps from RRR to itself are always just scalar multiplication. Specifically we get αR(r)=αR(1)⋅r\alpha_R(r) = \alpha_R(1) \cdot rαR​(r)=αR​(1)⋅r
Now for every m∈Mm \in Mm∈M, consider the RRR-linear map pm:R→Mp_m: R \to Mpm​:R→M which maps 1∈R1 \in R1∈R to mmm, so pm(r)=r⋅mp_m(r) = r \cdot mpm​(r)=r⋅m
Then using naturality we get αR(m)=αR(pm(1))=pm(αR(1))=αR(1)⋅m\alpha_R(m) = \alpha_R(p_m(1)) = p_m(\alpha_R(1)) = \alpha_R(1) \cdot mαR​(m)=αR​(pm​(1))=pm​(αR​(1))=αR​(1)⋅m
Thus every natural transformation from 1MOD(R)1_{MOD(R)}1MOD(R)​ to itself is given by scalar multiplication.
Nice! That's a faster, simpler, better version of my argument using the fact that every RRR-module is a quotient of a free one.
I wrote this up on the nLab.
There should be a way more general result for [[Tannakian reconstruction]] that covers these cases

In general if MMM is a monoid then MMM-acts form a category such that End(1MAct)≅Z(M)End(1_{MAct}) \cong Z(M)End(1MAct​)≅Z(M). This works for monoidal categories too! And for R modules, I guess it's the Ab-enriched version thereof.
Thanks! I guess the proof that @JS PL (he/him) and I came up with should handle these cases too.

Though for some reason I've been thinking about the case where the ring R (or the monoid M) is commutative, so I need to think a bit more about the noncommutative case (just for fun). Namely, why the obvious map from the center of M to End(1MAct)\mathrm{End}(1_{M\mathsf{Act}})End(1MAct​) is surjective. (The argument that it's injective still works.)
In the commutative case we used the fact that every endomorphism of MMM as a left MMM-set is given by left multiplication by an element of M=Z(M)M = Z(M)M=Z(M).
But when MMM is noncommutative that's no longer true; now every endomorphism of MMM as a left MMM-set is given by right multiplication by an element of MMM.
Yet somehow (you claim) central elements give all the natural transformations of the identity functor on MActM \mathsf{Act}MAct.
It's quite plausible, but why is it true? It must be easy.

In the non-commutative case, I believe @JS PL (he/him)'s proof goes through as-is except for the fact that when he argues linear maps R→RR \to RR→R have the form r⋅−r \cdot -r⋅− we now have to add that r∈Z(R)r \in Z(R)r∈Z(R), since rs=srrs = srrs=sr is exactly the property we need

No: as I said, all linear maps R→RR \to RR→R have the form −⋅r- \cdot r−⋅r. That is, right multiplication by elements of RRR. Of course when rrr is in the center of RRR we can also express these using left multiplication.
(By the way, I'm saying "linear maps" to be nice, but the mathematician in me is squirming: I want to say "left module endomorphisms". Life is tough for people like us!)

Anyway, so the challenge is to show that of all the left module endomorphisms of RRR, only those coming from right multiplication by elements in the center of RRR extend naturally to endomorphisms of all the other left modules.
I think this is probably pretty easy, but that's what has to be done.

John Baez said:

No: as I said, all linear maps R→RR \to RR→R have the form −⋅r- \cdot r−⋅r. That is, right multiplication by elements of RRR. Of course when rrr is in the center of RRR we can also express these using left multiplication.

Oh I see :thinking:

Ok here's a sketch of a proof, with a bunch of hazy details to be discussed (below, CCC is a cartesian category and RRR is a monoid in it):

Given α:1RAct⇒1RAct\alpha : 1_{RAct} \Rightarrow 1_{RAct}α:1RAct​⇒1RAct​, we want to show that for every m:Mm:Mm:M, there exists an r:Rr:Rr:R such that αM(m)=rm\alpha_M(m) = rmαM​(m)=rm (I'm using the internal language of RRR-Act).
If we prove this, then for M=RM=RM=R this ends up saying r−=−rr- = -rr−=−r, meaning r∈Z(R)r \in Z(R)r∈Z(R).
It seems to me it's enough to prove this fact for MMM free, since the naturality square for the quotient F→MF \to MF→M presenting MMM will then say αM=r−\alpha_M = r-αM​=r− for any other MMM.
For a free module FXFXFX, giving a map αFX:FX→FX\alpha_{FX} : FX \to FXαFX​:FX→FX is equivalent to a choice of map X→FXX \to FXX→FX in the underlying category. The free RRR-act has the form R×XR \times XR×X. So α\alphaα comes from a natural map α′:1C⇒R×1C\alpha' : 1_C \Rightarrow R \times 1_Cα′:1C​⇒R×1C​, where CCC is the base category (where RRR,XXX live in). Natural maps of that kind decompose in (1) a 'choice of scalar' 1C⇒R1_C \Rightarrow R1C​⇒R and (2) a map α0:1C⇒1C\alpha_0 : 1_C \Rightarrow 1_Cα0​:1C​⇒1C​.

I guess this second part is irreducible--and it makes sense: any natural endomorphism of the identity of CCC surely induces a similar one in RActRActRAct. If we assume End(1C)=1End(1_C) = 1End(1C​)=1 (which is true for something like Set), then α0\alpha_0α0​ must be trivial. In generality though, this shows the theorem should really be something like 'End(1RAct(C))=Z(R)×End(1C)End(1_{RAct(C)}) = Z(R) \times End(1_{C})End(1RAct(C)​)=Z(R)×End(1C​)'.

Which brings us to the second problem, what are transformations ρ:1C⇒R\rho : 1_C \Rightarrow Rρ:1C​⇒R? These should be 'elements of RRR', in some way. Naturality tells us the components of ρ\rhoρ are constant. Again, in something pedestrian like Set ρ\rhoρ is given by picking an element in RRR.

So with the above two caveats, we now know α′\alpha'α′ is given by a scalar r∈Rr \in Rr∈R, meaning αFX\alpha_{FX}αFX​ is defined as (s,x)↦(r,s,x)↦(rs,x)(s, x) \mapsto (r, s, x) \mapsto (rs, x)(s,x)↦(r,s,x)↦(rs,x), i.e. αFX=r−\alpha_{FX} = r-αFX​=r−, as desired.

So probably a more accurate conjecture is something like End(1RAct(C))=Z(1C⇒R)⊗End(1C)End(1_{RAct(C)}) = Z(1_C \Rightarrow R) \otimes End(1_{C})End(1RAct(C)​)=Z(1C​⇒R)⊗End(1C​), where ⊗\otimes⊗ is the copowering of CCC.
In many cases 1C⇒R1_C \Rightarrow R1C​⇒R should simplify to C(1,R)C(1, R)C(1,R), i.e. the global elements of RRR

Matteo Capucci (he/him) said:

So with the above two caveats, we now know α′\alpha'α′ is given by a scalar r∈Rr \in Rr∈R, meaning αFX\alpha_{FX}αFX​ is defined as (s,x)↦(r,s,x)↦(rs,x)(s, x) \mapsto (r, s, x) \mapsto (rs, x)(s,x)↦(r,s,x)↦(rs,x), i.e. αFX=r−\alpha_{FX} = r-αFX​=r−, as desired.

Ouch actually this goes (s,x)↦(s,r,x)↦(sr,x)(s,x) \mapsto (s, r,x) \mapsto (sr, x)(s,x)↦(s,r,x)↦(sr,x) which is the wrong side...
Or maybe this just proves ZZZ isn't needed?
Let me a take a try at it - I'll only tackle the case of rings and modules, not monoids in a general monoidal category, and I'll talk a lot more like a ring theorist than a category theorist.

My goal was to show that for any ring RRR, End(1RMod) \mathsf{End}(1_{R \mathsf{Mod}})End(1RMod​) is the center of RRR. To prove this, one task remained:

Anyway, so the challenge is to show that of all the left module endomorphisms of RRR, only those coming from right multiplication by elements in the center of RRR extend naturally to endomorphisms of all the other left modules.

First, just to warm up, it's well-known that for any ring RRR, every endomorphism of RRR as a left RRR-module, say f:R→Rf: R \to Rf:R→R, is given by right multiplication by some r∈Rr \in Rr∈R. But it's easy to show so let's show it! Let f(1)=rf(1) = rf(1)=r. Then for any x∈Rx \in Rx∈R we have

f(x)=f(x1)=xf(1)=xr f(x) = f(x 1) = x f(1) = x rf(x)=f(x1)=xf(1)=xr

Done.

Now, suppose α:1RMod→1RMod\alpha: 1_{R \mathsf{Mod}} \to 1_{R \mathsf{Mod}}α:1RMod​→1RMod​ is a natural transformation of the identity. αR:R→R\alpha_R: R \to RαR​:R→R is some endomorphism of RRR as a left RRR-module, so as we've just seen, for some s∈Rs \in Rs∈R we have

αR(x)=xs \alpha_R(x) = x sαR​(x)=xs

for all x∈Rx \in Rx∈R.
But for α\alphaα to be natural, a commutative square condition needs to hold. In particular αR\alpha_RαR​ needs to commute with any left RRR-module endomorphism f:R→Rf: R \to Rf:R→R.

Take fff as above; then

αR(f(x))=xrs \alpha_R(f(x)) = x r s αR​(f(x))=xrs

while

f(αR(x))=xsr f(\alpha_R(x)) = x s r f(αR​(x))=xsr

Since this is true for all fff, i.e. all rrr, sss must be in the center of RRR!

Done.

And why did we care about this? Because we know α\alphaα must act as left multiplication by this central element rrr on every module MMM. @JS PL (he/him) showed it in the commutative case but let me check that the argument works in general. For any M∈RModM \in R\mathsf{Mod}M∈RMod and any m∈Mm \in Mm∈M there's a unique left RRR-module homomorphism g:R→Mg: R \to Mg:R→M with g(1)=mg(1) = mg(1)=m, namely the one with

g(x)=xmg(x) = xmg(x)=xm

for all x∈Rx \in Rx∈R.

By naturality we get a commutative square that says

αM∘g=g∘αR \alpha_M \circ g = g \circ \alpha_RαM​∘g=g∘αR​

but

αM(g(1))=αM(m) \alpha_M (g(1)) = \alpha_M (m) αM​(g(1))=αM​(m)

while

g(αR(1))=g(r)=rm g (\alpha_R(1)) = g(r) = r mg(αR​(1))=g(r)=rm

so

αM(m)=rm \alpha_M(m) = r mαM​(m)=rm
Done!
This completes the proof that for any ring RRR, End(1RMod) \mathsf{End}(1_{R \mathsf{Mod}})End(1RMod​) is the center of RRR.

For the record, this is where I went wrong:

For a free module FXFXFX, giving a map αFX:FX→FX\alpha_{FX} : FX \to FXαFX​:FX→FX is equivalent to a choice of map X→FXX \to FXX→FX in the underlying category. The free RRR-act has the form R×XR \times XR×X. So α\alphaα comes from a natural map α′:1C⇒R×1C\alpha' : 1_C \Rightarrow R \times 1_Cα′:1C​⇒R×1C​, where CCC is the base category (where RRR,XXX live in).

We can't get α′\alpha'α′ of that form from α\alphaα.

John Baez said:

Let me a take a try at it - I'll only tackle the case of rings and modules, not monoids in a general monoidal category, and I'll talk a lot more like a ring theorist than a category theorist.

It seems to me your proof actually ends up working for arbitrary monoid objects, am I right?
I used a fact that's true for rings (and monoids) that I don't know how to correctly state for monoid objects in general.
Namely, for a monoid M (in Set) every map of left M-sets from M to M is given by right multiplication by some element of M.
Then I used this: every natural transformation of the identity functor on MSet is determined by its value on M.

John Baez said:

Namely, for a monoid M (in Set) every map of left M-sets from M to M is given by right multiplication by some element of M.

That's an instance of the Yoneda lemma for one-object categories. And the Yoneda lemma is true for categories enriched over any monoidal category, hence also for one-object ones, i.e. monoid objects. At least if the monoidal category is closed and complete, you can state the result by saying that MMM is isomorphic to the object of left MMM-set maps from MMM to MMM, the latter defined as a subobject of the internal-hom cut out by an equalizer.

John Baez said:

First, just to warm up, it's well-known that for any ring $R$, every endomorphism of $R$ as a left $R$-module, say $f: R \to R$, is given by right multiplication by some $r \in R$. But it's easy to show so let's show it! Let $f(1) = r$. Then for any $x \in R$ we have

$ f(x) = f(x 1) = x f(1) = x r$

Done.

Also this proof works for monoids, doesn't it?

Yes, the whole proof never needs addition. So it works for monoids... and also rigs, and also rings. But at least as stands, it does use some other things peculiar to the fact that we're working in the category of sets. Mike Shulman tried to explicate some of those... but I want to add that unless we're in a symmetric monoidal category the concept of the 'center' doesn't make sense. (Or braided, but that gets very tricky.)
So, it would be a nice project to figure out how much we can generalize.
I wouldn't be surprised if someone had already done this.
